47.26.text: At the start of Book 7 of his masterpiece, "The Republic",

50.96.text: Plato tells us about some people living imprisoned in a cave

54.78.text: They've always lived there and don't know anything of the outside world.

58.68.text: There is no natural light in this cave, the walls are damp and dark

105.22.text: Gradually his eyes adjust and he encounters the true forms

108.88.text: of all those things which he had formerly know only as shadows

112.82.text: He sees actual flowers, the colors of birds, the nuances in the bark of trees

118.30.text: He observes stars and grasps the vastness and sublime nature of the universe

242.26.text: The solution, Plato says, is a process of widespread carefully administered philosophical education

248.70.text: By which he understood the method of inquiry pioneered by Socrates and known to us as the "Socratic Method"

255.48.text: It's a very gentle process. You don't lecture or harang or force someone to read a particular book

261.48.text: You just start with a general declaration of intellectual modesty no one knows very much

266.38.text: It's always good to insist: "wisdom starts with owning up to ignorance"

277.30.text: You then get the other person to say what they think and gradually together you investigate the answers

292.20.text: You must be supremely patient with this kind of bravado
